text.p: Tribune Co., publisher of the Chicago Tribune, said Friday its net income rose 11 percent in the second quarter, bolstered by strong returns from its publishing, broadcasting and entertainment businesses.

Excluding gains from special items, the company registered profits of $93 million during the quarter, up from $84 million in the same year-ago period. Earnings per share rose to 72 cents, from 65 cents a share a year ago.
Higher advertising sales and lower newsprint prices drove publishing operating profits up by 27 percent, to $92 million, a record for the second quarter.
"Our publishing group had an outstanding second quarter with excellent revenue growth led by classified advertising," Chairman John Madigan said in a statement.
The company said the earnings growth was partially offset by higher net interest expense.
Interest expense more than doubled from last year, climbing to $25 million from $11 million, due to higher debt levels resulting from acquisitions and stock repurchases.
The company owns 16 television stations, 4 radio stations and 3 newspapers besides the Tribune. It is also the owner of the Chicago Cubs baseball team.
Tribune's stock slipped 12.5 cents to $53.4375 on the New York Stock Exchange at midday.

Newspaper companies have benefited from robust advertising revenues this quarter. The New York Times Co., parent of The New York Times and The Boston Globe, Thursday reported that its second-quarter profits climbed 80 percent to $84.9 million.
